Two months to go before Britain’s Prince Harry transforms his American sweetheart into a bride and a full-fledged member of the royal family. The venue has long been booked, but just who will be entering the doors of St. George’s chapel to witness the matrimony?

Who will make the cut on the guest list? What role will two future kings — Harry’s brother, Prince William, and his nephew, Prince George — play in the ceremony? And what will the world call Markle after she formally becomes royalty?

Prince Harry and Meghan Markle want the public to feel part of their celebration as much as possible. Chris Jackson / Getty Images

While some of the answers won’t be known until the actual event, we’ll try to tackle some of the burning questions about the upcoming wedding of the year. Kensington Palace, the official residence and office of the engaged couple, has provided a few details already. We’ll try to fill in some others.

The big day: What, when and where?

The couple revealed their May 19, 2018, wedding date shortly after they publicly announced their engagement. With the blessing of Harry’s grandmother Queen Elizabeth, the ceremony will take place in St. George’s Chapel on the grounds of Windsor Castle. Harry was christened inside the 15th century gothic chapel, which can seat about 800 people. Compare that to the 1,900 guests that Prince William and the former Kate Middleton invited to their 2011 wedding at Westminster Abbey.

The event is expected to be televised, but Americans who want to watch from home will have to set their alarm clocks: The service will begin at noon local time — which means 7 a.m. for folks on the East Coast, and 4 a.m. for West Coast viewers.

The couple to hold the ceremony at St. George's Chapel, located on the grounds of the royal residence in Windsor, England. AFP - Getty Images

For those who live in or plan to head to Windsor, it may be possible to catch a glimpse of the couple on their special day. Harry and Markle will open up the castle grounds (which is normally open to tourists but will be closed on the wedding day) to some local school children, charity workers and select individuals chosen by local leaders throughout the United Kingdom.

The rest of the public will have to join the crowds lined along the route of a carriage procession transporting the couple through the streets of Windsor once the two have tied the knot.

Harry and Markle will ride in a carriage following their ceremony, just as Duke and Duchess of Cambridge did after their April 2011 wedding. Tom Stoddart / Getty Images

Who will be in the wedding party?

Don’t be fooled by the 2011 wedding of William and Kate, now known as the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. While that ceremony included Prince Harry as his brother’s best man and Kate’s sister, Pippa, as maid of honor, royal weddings don’t typically include parties like the ones compiled by American brides and grooms.

“Historically, there’s no such thing as a best man in a royal wedding,” said Marlene Koenig, an academic librarian who has studied British and European royalty. Instead, the best man equivalent is known as a “supporter.”

Prince William and his new bride Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge walk down the aisle followed by best man Prince Harry and Maid of Honor Pippa Middleton at the close of their wedding ceremony at Westminster Abbey on April 29, 2011 in London. WPA Pool / Getty Images

When asked in a January interview about his brother’s wedding, William joked: “He hasn’t asked me yet, just to clear that up. It could be a sensitive subject.”

But the two have a close relationship, forged in part during their recovery from the 1997 death of their mother Princess Diana. So it’s a safe bet that William will stand beside Harry at the wedding, regardless of what his role will be officially called.

The two princes are close, but will Prince Harry ask his brother to be best man? Samir Hussein / WireImage

Among Markle's close friends, meanwhile, it remains to be seen whether they will join her near the altar as as bridesmaids or in the pews as regular guests. That's because royal weddings traditional have young children serve as bridesmaids — and pages.

Among the ladies royal watchers expect to see at the wedding in one role or another are her “Suits” co-star Abigail Spencer and tennis queen Serena Williams.

Will the Obamas be coming to the wedding?

Former President Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle, have had a warm friendship with Prince Harry, as well as his brother Prince William. (Remember the time the Obamas met a robe-clad Prince George inside Kensington Palace?)

The Obamas have worked together with Harry on numerous occasions, including a luncheon for military families and at the annual event dear to the prince's heart, the Invictus Games, the Paralympic-style competition for wounded veterans.

Unfortunately for you @FLOTUS and @POTUS I wasn't alone when you sent me that video 😉 - H.https://t.co/sjfSQvkzb6 — Kensington Palace (@KensingtonRoyal) April 29, 2016

When Harry was asked on a BBC radio show in late December whether he planned to invite the former American president, the prince eluded giving a direct answer.

“I don’t know about that — we haven’t even put the invites or the guest list together yet so who knows whether he’s going to be invited or not," he said. "I wouldn't want to ruin that surprise."
